questions.question: What is the most important mechanism of antiepileptic activity of phenytoin?
A known case of seizure disorder has been on long-term phenytoin therapy. Which of thefollowing statements about this drug would be incorrect?

options.B: Metabolism follows only zero order kinetics
options.D: Metabolized extensively by the CYP enzymes in the liver

questions.explanation: Phenytoin follows first-order kinetics at lower concentrations and as the concentration increases,the elimination changes to zero-order kinetics. The rate of elimination of phenytoin varies withthe serum concentration.As the blood levels rise, the maximal capacity of the liver to metabolize phenytoin is reached. Thuseven a small increase in the dosage can result in disproportionally high plasma levels. Therefore,it requires therapeutic drug monitoring.About 90% of phenytoin is bound to plasma proteins, mainly albumin. Phenytoin is metabolizedby the CYP enzymes in the liver.

questions.question: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding fosphenytoin?

options.B: Fosphenytoin displaces phenytoin from protein-binding sites
options.C: Causes hyperphosphatemia in renal failure patients
options.D: ECG monitoring is not required when administering IV

questions.explanation: Fosphenytoin like phenytoin requires continuous ECG monitoring during IV infusion due to therisk of arrhythmias.Fosphenytoin is a water-soluble prodrug of phenytoin. Fosphenytoin is also extensively proteinbound, mainly albumin. This binding is saturable and fosphenytoin displaces phenytoin fromprotein-binding sites.Hydrolysis of fosphenytoin yields phosphate, which increases the risk of hyperphosphatemia inpatients with renal failure. It is contraindicated in patients with sinus bradycardia, sino-atrialblock, second and third-degree A-V block.278

questions.question: A patient presenting to the ER with generalized tonic-clonic seizures is started on phenytointherapy. All of the following adverse effects can be expected in this patient except?
questions.explanation: Phenytoin causes hypocalcemia and hyperglycemia.It interferes with the metabolism of vitamin D and intestinal calcium absorption and results inhypocalcemia. Hyperglycemia and glycosuria can be seen due to the inhibition of insulinsecretion.Long-term usage of phenytoin can also cause cutaneous pseudolymphoma which is mainly T-cellpredominant.

questions.question: Which of the following features would you not expect to find in a baby born to a woman onphenytoin therapy?
questions.explanation: The newborn baby is unlikely to have gum hyperplasia. A baby born to a pregnant mother whowas on phenytoin therapy will be suffering from fetal hydantoin syndrome.Features of fetal hydantoin syndrome are:•Microcephaly•Digital hypoplasia• Cleft lip/ cleft palateGum hyperplasia is the most common adverse effect of phenytoin in children and youngadolescents on chronic use.

questions.question: A patient with recent-onset primary generalized epilepsy develops a skin reaction due tophenytoin sodium. What is the most appropriate course of action?

options.B: Stop and restart phenytoin sodium after two weeks

questions.explanation: Hypersensitivity reaction to phenytoin warrants discontinuation of the drug. Switching to sodiumvalproate is the most appropriate course of action for this patient.Sodium valproate is one of the first-line agents indicated for GTCS. Clonazepam and ethosuximideare primarily used in absence seizures and are not indicated for GTCS.Clonazepam is indicated as adjunctive therapy in the absence seizures when first-line agents(ethosuximide, sodium valproate, lamotrigine) fail to control the seizures adequately.

questions.question: A 51-year-old male complains of severe, sharp, piercing intermittent electrical shock-like painsensation on the left side of his face. The pain was triggered by talking, washing his face,eating, and brushing his teeth. Which of the following drugs is most effective to treat thispatient?
questions.explanation: The clinical features in this patient are suggestive of a diagnosis of trigeminal neuralgia andcarbamazepine is the most effective agent for its treatment.If carbamazepine is ineffective, then second-line agents like lamotrigine and phenytoin are used.Sodium valproate although effective for trigeminal neuralgia lacks enough evidence for use.279

questions.question: 270Which of the following statements is true about carbamazepine?

options.A: It is indicated in focal seizures with impaired awareness
options.D: It is the drug of choice for status epilepticus

questions.explanation: Carbamazepine is indicated in focal seizures with impaired awareness.Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic drug that acts by prolonging the inactivated state of the Na+channel similar to phenytoin. It is used in:• Focal seizures with impaired awareness• Focal seizures with intact awareness• Generalized tonic-clonic seizures.Trigeminal and related neuralgias• Manic depressive psychosis.Option B: Carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer. It is a substrate as well as an inducer of CYP3A4and CYP2C9.Option C: Carbamazepine causes hyponatremia and not hypernatremia. Other side effects ofcarbamazepine include agranulocytosis or aplastic anemia, hepatotoxicity, water retention andhyponatremia (by potentiating ADH action), and dose-related neurotoxicity.Option D: It is not used in status epilepticus. Lorazepam is the drug of choice for statusepilepticus.

questions.question: If carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, what adverse effect is risked?
questions.explanation: If carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, it can result in hepatotoxicity.A combination of valproate and carbamazepine increases hepatotoxicity. Valproic acid may inhibitcarbamazepine clearance and increase steady-state carbamazepine blood levels.

questions.question: In patients recieving carbamazepine, which of the following idiosyncratic reactions are notexpected to occur?
questions.explanation: Peripheral neuropathy is not an idiosyncratic reaction that can occur after carbamazepine use. Itis a dose-dependent CNS adverse effect. It can be minimized by gradually increasing the dosefrom initiation or reducing the maintenance dose.Idiosyncratic reactions are hypersensitivity reactions like:•Rash• Steven-Johnson syndrome•⚫ Eosinophilia•Lymphadenopathy.Diplopia280Serious hematological toxicity includes aplastic anemia and agranulocytosis.

questions.question: A 70-year-old man is on carbamazepine therapy. Which of the following is expected to occurin this patient?
questions.explanation: Carbamazepine is expected to cause hyponatremia in this patient.Carbamazepine potentiates the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result in waterretention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiacdisease.

questions.question: 271An 8-year-old child diagnosed to have focal seizures was initiated on oxcarbazepine. Which ofthe following would be incorrect regarding the agent being used?

options.B: Enzyme induction potency is less when compared to carbamazepineMetabolised by glucuronide conjugationd) Hyponatremia risk is less when compared to carbamazepineQuestion 13:A neonate diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma was started on vincristine, cyclophosphamide,and cisplatin. A week after initiation of treatment, the baby had multiple episodes of seizures,refractory to diazepam and lidocaine. Workup revealed an elevated ADH level and euvolemichyponatremia. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat this patient?a) Carbamazepineb) Phenytoin

questions.explanation: The risk of hyponatremia with oxcarbazepine is higher when compared to carbamazepine.Option A: Oxcarbazepine is a keto analog of carbamazepine. It is a prodrug. The mechanism ofaction of oxcarbazepine is by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels (same as carbamazepine).Option C: Active form is metabolized by glucuronide conjugation.Option B: Oxcarbazepine does not cause auto-induction of metabolizing enzymes. It can induceCYP enzymes but less potent when compared to carbamazepine.

questions.question: A 5th-grade student, after receiving multiple complaints from teachers at school for repeatedepisodes of inattention was brought to the OPD. The mother gave a history that her child hadbrief spells of staring associated with lip-smacking movements. Which anti-epileptic drug isthe most effective for this child?
questions.explanation: The clinical features are suggestive of absence seizures and ethosuximide is the most effectiveagent for this condition.First-line drugs in:•Typical absence seizures: Ethosuximide (drug of choice), valproate, lamotrigine• Atypical absence seizures: Sodium valproate281

questions.question: A child with absence seizures improves after being treated with ethosuximide. Which of thefollowing is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation: The mechanism of action of ethosuximide is by inhibition of T-type Ca2+ channels in thalamicneurons at clinically relevant concentrations.It also affects other ion channels affected include voltage-gated sodium channels and potassiumchannels.

questions.question: A 10-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of vacant stares lasting for about halfa minute. The EEG shows a characteristic 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Which of thefollowing drugs can be used for this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of absence seizures. Ethosuximide and valproate are thefirst-line drugs in this condition.Absence seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without loss ofpostural control. There is no postictal confusion. The following subtle motor signs mayaccompany the episodes•Rapid blinking of the eyelids• Chewing movements• Small-amplitude clonic movements of the handsHyperventilation has a tendency to provoke absence seizures. First-line drugs include:•Typical absence seizures: Ethosuximide (drug of choice), valproate, lamotrigine• Atypical absence seizures: Valproate

questions.question: Which of the following is not an enzyme inducer?
questions.explanation: Sodium valproate is not an enzyme inducer. It is metabolized by CYP2C9/19 and is an inhibitor ofCYP2C9.Phenytoin, phenobarbital, and carbamazepine are inducers of CYP and UGT enzymes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of sodium valproate?

options.B: Inhibition of T type Ca2+ channels

questions.explanation: Sodium valproate has no action on the GABA transporter.Mechanism of action of sodium valproate:•Prolongation of sodium channel inactivation• Inhibition of T-type Ca2+ channels•Inhibition of GABA transaminase282• Increases GABA synthesis from glutamic acid.

questions.question: Which of the following are not adverse effects of sodium valproate?
questions.explanation: Osteomalacia is not an adverse effect of sodium valproate.The side effects of valproate (mnemonic: VALPROATE)•Vomiting• Alopecia• Liver toxicity• Pancreatitis• Rash•Obesity•Anorexia• Teratogenicity (most common: spina bifida), thrombocytopenia, tremors• Edema

questions.question: Which of the following antiepileptic drugs does not cause fulminant hepatitis as a seriouscomplication?
questions.explanation: Vigabatrin is not associated with fulminant hepatitis. It is largely excreted unchanged in urinewithout undergoing any hepatic metabolism.Sodium valproate, felbamate and phenytoin are associated with fulminant hepatitis.

questions.question: A 23-year-old female patient is admitted to the neurology ward for evaluation of GTCS. Shereports that she has been on oral contraceptive pills for the past 6 months. Which of thefollowing drugs would you prescribe to this patient?
questions.explanation: Valproate is the drug used for this patient as it does not cause contraceptive failure.Valproate is an enzyme inhibitor and it inhibits the degradation of OCPs. OCPs thus have a longerduration of action and less incidence of contraceptive failure with valproate.However, other antiepileptic drugs like carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, primidone,oxcarbazepine, topiramate are enzyme inducers. They cause increased degradation of OCPs andhence lead to contraceptive failure.

questions.question: A 16-year-old patient was brought to the ER with bilateral jerking movements of arms. EEGrevealed diffuse, symmetric, bilateral 4-6 Hz polyspike and wave discharges with afrontocentral predominance. What is the most appropriate drug for this patient?
questions.explanation: The clinical features and EEG findings are suggestive of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The mostappropriate drug for management is sodium valproate.283In patients with myoclonic seizures which are refractory to valproate, clonazepam or clobazammay be added.

questions.question: 274A 55-year-old man visits the neurology OPD with complaints of tremors in both his handswhich improve on alcohol intake. On examination, there is a significant worsening of tremorstowards the end of finger-to-nose testing and head-nodding movements. Which antiepilepticis approved for use in this condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of essential tremors in this patient. Primidone isconsidered to be the first-line therapy for the same along with propranolol.Bilateral, symmetric tremors involving the hands associated with head nodding (titubation) andworsening of tremors towards the end of goal-directed movements such as drinking from a glassor finger-to-nose testing is suggestive of essential tremors.Primidone is a barbiturate and functions as a GABA enhancer. It is an enzyme inducer. It is usedin the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic seizures and partial seizures.It has side effects like sedation, ataxia, and hyperactivity.

questions.question: Pseudolymphoma may occur in patients on long-term therapy with:
questions.explanation: Phenytoin on long-term use can result in pseudolymphoma.This lymphadenopathy can be difficult to distinguish from malignant lymphoma. Although somestudies suggest a causal relationship between phenytoin use and Hodgkin's disease, the data arefar from conclusive. Almost all lesions are benign and termed as pseudolymphoma.

questions.question: What is the most common adverse effect of phenytoin in children and young adolescents onchronic use?
questions.explanation: Gingival hyperplasia occurs in patients on chronic phenytoin therapy. It is the most commonmanifestation in children and young adolescents.Gingival hyperplasia due to phenytoin therapy occurs due to tissue overgrowth secondary toaltered collagen metabolism. The toothless portion of gums is not involved. It does not warrantdiscontinuation of the drug. It can be minimized by maintaining good oral hygiene.

questions.question: Which of the following is a carbamazepine analogue that has an advantage of once dailydosing?
questions.explanation: Eslicarbazepine acetate is an analog of carbamazepine that has the advantage of once-dailydosing. It is a prodrug and is rapidly converted to active licarbazepine.Oxcarbazepine is an analog of carbamazepine that is also converted to licarbazepine.Oxcarbazepine does not have the advantage of once-daily dosing like eslicarbazepine acetate.Dacarbazine is not a carbamazepine analog like the other drugs and is a chemotherapy medicationused in the treatment of melanoma and Hodgkin's lymphoma.284

questions.question: A patient with a history of mitral stenosis presents with the given intractable finding that isrefractory to conventional therapy. What is the drug of choice?
questions.explanation: The drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea is sodium valproate, as it doesn't haveextrapyramidal side effects.Sydenham's chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements which mainlyaffect the head and upper limbs. In the tongue, it is visible as the characteristic dartingmovements.Medications used to treat Sydenham chorea are:• Mild cases - Providing a calm environment.••Severe cases:Dopamine antagonists - haloperidol, pimozide• Antiepileptic medications - sodium valproate, carbamazepine.• Severe, refractory cases - Steroids (thought to be immune-mediated)•IV immunoglobulins, plasmapheresis - limited studies, decreased efficacy (not currentlyrecommended)

questions.question: A 10-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of vacant stares lasting for about halfa minute. The EEG shows <3 Hz spike and wave pattern. The first-line drug for themanagement of this condition is:
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and <3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG is suggestive ofatypical absence seizures. The first-line drug in the treatment of atypical absence seizures issodium valproate.Symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG is seen in typical absence seizures. First-linedrugs in its treatment include:•Ethosuximide (drug of choice)• Valproate• Lamotrigine

questions.question: 276An 18-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaints of excessive growth of hair onher face and chest. She is a known case of epilepsy and is on treatment with phenytoin.Which of the following drugs would not cause this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette of excessive hair growth secondary to treatment with phenytoin issuggestive of hirsutism. Amantadine does not cause hirsutism or hypertrichosis but itscharacteristic side effect is livedo reticularis (bluish discoloration of the skin).Following are the drugs causing hirsutism:•Phenytoin• Anabolic steroids285⚫ Danazol••.MetoclopramideMethyldopa• Phenothiazines• Progestins• Reserpine• TestosteroneFollowing are the drugs causing hypertrichosis:•Cyclosporine• Diazoxide⚫ Hydrocortisone• Minoxidil• Penicillamine•Phenytoin• Psoralens• Streptomycin286
